awd_titl_txt: Northern California Math and Science Teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
The Northern California Math and Science Teachers project aims to advance the national need for preparing and retaining qualified math and science teachers in high-need schools. This Track 1 Noyce project at California State University (CSU), Chico, will support the education of 25 students to become highly qualified teachers who are prepared to succeed in diverse classrooms. The project will provide scholarships to undergraduate math and science majors, as well as post-baccalaureate STEM credential candidates. The project will explore how undergraduate experiential learning opportunities, such as summer undergraduate research experiences and serving as learning assistants, affect teacher retention. Reports from the National Academy of Sciences recommend that student become involved with faculty mentors and professional activities early in their undergraduate training. The project responds to this recommendation by requiring each scholar to attend a seminar course focused on research-based practices that support secondary learners in the northern California region.  These practices include place-based learning, grit, and growth mindset. The results from this work may provide evidence for improving existing STEM education and teacher education programs and broaden support for undergraduate research. 

This project will examine the impact of experiential learning opportunities on undergraduate and pre-service teachers through surveys, interviews, classroom observations, and performance on course assignments. Specifically, the project will attempt to answer the following questions: (1) What demographic, educational, occupational variables, or other information about Noyce scholars predict their behavior throughout and after the program?  (2) What are the most successful recruitment and marketing strategies for attracting a large and diverse pool of math and science teachers? and (3) How effective are various retention strategies? To inform and improve practices, the project team will share findings across departments at CSU-Chico, via department meetings, newsletters, and evaluations of the undergraduate experiences. Findings will also be disseminated at regional conferences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NorCal MAST program, which received funding from the Noyce Scholarship and support from the National Science Foundation, has had a significant impact on preparing and supporting future math and science teachers for high-need schools in Northern California. Throughout the program, 45 scholars were granted Noyce Scholarships, allowing them to pursue teaching credentials in mathematics and science at California State University, Chico. This initiative effectively addressed the critical need for qualified educators in these fields, particularly in underserved communities, offering a promising solution to a pressing issue.
The program was designed with a strong emphasis on enhancing the quality of teacher preparation, ensuring that scholars were knowledgeable in their subject areas and equipped with the pedagogical skills necessary to succeed in diverse and challenging classroom environments. Scholars in the NorCal MAST program participated in comprehensive training that combined theoretical coursework with practical, hands-on teaching experience. This approach allowed them to apply what they learned in real-world settings, preparing them to effectively teach students from a variety of backgrounds, including those from low socioeconomic areas or with limited access to educational resources.
One of the program's key strengths was its focus on preparing teachers to address the unique challenges found in high-need schools. Scholars were trained to develop and implement innovative teaching strategies tailored to meet the specific needs of their students. This training included understanding the social, economic, and cultural factors that affect student learning and how to create inclusive and supportive classroom environments. This emphasis on equity and inclusivity is not just a strength but an inspiration, as it shows the program's commitment to creating a fair and supportive learning environment for all students.
The NorCal MAST program has had far-reaching effects that go beyond the scholars who took part. By placing dedicated and well-prepared educators in schools with significant needs, the program significantly impacted the students in those communities. These teachers brought extensive subject knowledge and a thorough awareness of their students' obstacles. Their adeptness in utilizing progressive teaching techniques and fostering supportive learning atmospheres resulted in enhanced academic achievements in the schools where they were based.
Moreover, the program's focus on recruiting and supporting underrepresented groups in the teaching profession helped to diversify the pool of educators, bringing a more comprehensive range of perspectives and experiences into the classroom. This diversity is crucial for creating educational environments that reflect the backgrounds of the students being served and for promoting equity in education. The program's efforts in this area have helped to ensure that more students have access to teachers who understand their unique needs and can serve as role models in their educational journey.
The NorCal MAST program has significantly contributed to the field of education by training a new generation of math and science teachers specifically equipped to work in high-need schools. The program's results have enhanced the quality of education in these communities and established a model for future efforts to address teacher shortages and promote educational equity. The success of the NorCal MAST program underscores the importance of tailored teacher preparation programs in meeting the needs of underserved communities and emphasizes the potential for similar initiatives to have a lasting impact on the education system.


Last Modified: 08/15/2024
Modified by: Jennifer Oloff-Lewis
